description: Learned borrowing from Ancient Greek σύναψις (súnapsis, “conjunction”), from συνάπτω (sunáptō, “to clasp”). Introduced by neurophysiologist Charles Scott Sherrington.

entries.meaning: The junction between the terminal of a neuron and either another neuron or a muscle or gland cell, over which nerve impulses pass.

verbs.description: synapse (third-person singular simple present synapses, present participle synapsing, simple past and past participle synapsed)
